newsitem.title: UK: BA says can wait for EC on American deal.
newsitem.headline: BA says can wait for EC on American deal.

text.p: British Airways Plc said it was not surprised by a report on Tuesday that the European Commission (EC) was unlikely to pass verdict on its proposed alliance with American Airlines before the end of August.

"We are well aware of the the Commission's procedures in such matters of competition and we thought it quite likely that approval would not happen until after the EC's summer break," a spokesman for the airline said.

Earlier, EU Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert had told reporters in Brussels that the Commission was unlikely to rule before September because a final recommendation was unlikely to be adopted before the Commission's summer recess in August.
Van Miert met with BA's chief executive Robert Ayling to discuss the proposed alliance on Monday.
"Our view all along has been that the timing is not the issue; the end result is," said the BA spokesman.
"Robert Ayling yesterday attended a constructive meeting with Mr Van Miert which was held in a friendly atmosphere."

The year-long campaign to get the controversial alliance approved shifts to the U.S. on Wednesday with Ayling and and American's chairamn Robert Crandall both due to give evidence to a U.S. Senate hearing in Washington.

"We have high hopes of progress in the USA tomorrow when Bob Ayling and Bob Crandall both appear at the Senate Aviation hearing where the two airlines will explain the competition benefits the alliance will bring across the North Atlantic (market)," the spokesman said.
